🎯 Key Takeaways for quick navigation:  01:18 🚶‍♂️ Parametric equations provide a more convenient way to describe lines, representing the trajectory of a moving point in space over time. 03:43 📝 Parametric equations for lines can be defined using two points on the line. The moving point's position is expressed as a function of time, allowing the derivation of equations for any point on the line. 09:53 📊 The general form of parametric equations for lines is x(t) = constant + constant * t, y(t) = constant + constant * t, z(t) = constant + constant * t. The coefficients indicate the direction along the line, and the constants determine the position at t=0. 15:57 🧭 To determine if a line intersects a plane and where, plug the parametric equations of the line into the plane's equation. If the resulting equation has a solution, the line intersects the plane; otherwise, it is parallel or contained within the plane. 20:47 📍 If the line and plane intersect, finding the time (t) when the moving point hits the plane allows determining the intersection point. If t is a solution, the line and plane intersect at that point. 24:46 🔄 If the coefficient of t in the equation (resulting from intersecting the line and plane) is zero, the line is parallel to the plane. If the coefficient is nonzero, it indicates the line's perpendicularity or intersection with the plane. 25:13 🔄 Parametric equations are versatile, applicable not only to lines but also to any curve or trajectory traced by a moving point in space. 28:12 🔄 The cycloid, a curve traced by a point on a rolling wheel, is an example of using parametric equations to describe complex motions in space. 30:26 🔄 The cycloid trajectory involves the wheel rotating, creating arches as the red point moves up and down. 32:10 🔄 Instead of using time as a parameter, the angle (theta) of the wheel rotation is chosen to describe the position of point P. 35:27 🔄 Vector analysis simplifies the problem by breaking it down into three vectors: OA, AB, and BP. 40:52 🔄 The position vector OP is the sum of OA, AB, and BP, resulting in x(theta) and y(theta) as functions of the angle theta. 43:23 🔄 Examining the simplified equations, when a=1, reveals x(theta) = theta - sin(theta) and y(theta) = 1 - cos(theta). 50:33 🔄 Near thebottom point, as theta approaches zero, the curve exhibits a vertical tangent, indicating a downward and upward motion with infinite slope at the origin.  Made with HARPA AI

BTW, the cycloid is the solution to the famous Brachistochrone problem Johann Bernoulli posed in June of 1696 and the Tautochrone problem by Huygens in 1673. Both involve paths of least time.

@44:15 initially the formula is op=<a*theta-a*sin(theta),a-a*cos(theta)> but then let  a=radius  a=1 op=<theta-sin(theta),1-cos(theta)>  x(theta)=theta-sin(theta) y(theta)=1-cos(theta)  so here he parametrise the equation differently than before..  before when it was linear system  we can just use  formula  Q(t)=InitialQ+t*(EndQ-InitialQ) so if we have  InitialQ=<1,2,3> EndQ=<3,1,2>  we get  x(t)=1+2t y(t)=2-t z(t)=3-t  so for curvature and circle it is different than linear system to parametrize the equation

Yes you can also solve this way

You should take y(θ) = 1 - cos(θ) and find y'(θ) = sin(θ). Then, from x(θ) = θ - sin(θ) find x'(θ) = 1 - cos(θ). With this, find the limit when θ tends to 0 of y'(θ)/x'(θ) = 0/0, applying l'Hôpital's rule we get: limit when θ tends to 0 of cos(θ)/sin(θ) which is cot(θ) and tends to infinity.

Well, these are basic knowledge of plane vector. Only direction and magnitude matters. As the direction of AB is vertical and the length is a, it is (0, a) 这些国内初中就教过了诶
As for your first question, it's vector addition. You add OA and AB, you get OB. Then you add BP to OB to obtain OP.

theta is defined to be a measure of arc length - primarily the length of arc cut out by the angular interpretation of theta. The "a" you are referring to is the radius. You multiple by it to scale based on the radius.

The amount of radians in a full circle is defined to be 2π. Recall that circumference = 2π⋅r. So multiplying the radius of a circle by the amount of radians it has (2π if it's a full circle) will give you the circumference, and if you multiply 2π⋅r by 1/3, you'll get the circumference for 1/3 of a circle, f.e.

I absolutely hate Taylor Approximations. I just spent an hour obsessing over how he did the calculations in the last five minutes or so. My mistake was that I thought he was approximating the entire X and Y functions while he was just approximating sine and cosine. I got the same result either way but I hated to see my numbers not match his.  Anyway, I think I'm finally beginning to feel the effect of not actually being in the classroom with him. I bet he assigns homework and the students get lots of practice with the concepts we don't actually see. I'm not complaining because they're being generous just making this much open source. But it really comes out. He asks the questions on the board and gives them some time to come up with answers and the amount of time he gives them is not enough time for me to solve it. (But I've got a handy dandy pause button).   I never thought I'd say this, but I'm actually missing the homework problems. With calculus, the more times you try it, the quicker you are at it and the students obviously have more practice then those of us hanging out here.

YouTube is better

In any higher mathematics course, you will find that lectures are good as a supplement, but the main dish of the course is always the course material, i.e. a good textbook, and a set of exercises to solve yourself. As many mathematicians have noted, the only way to learn mathematics is to do mathematics. Merely listening to lectures or reading about the theory will perhaps give you a general understanding, but you will have no skill at applying the ideas yourself without training. It is like going to the gym and only watching people exercise, and then expecting to build muscle from it.

speedfork I absolutely agree. That is precisely the reason I invested $150 on the textbook. And the homework problems are very available on the course webpage at MIT. I do not intend to bother going to the gym if I can jog outside and buy weights at home. In either case, it's better to bother doing it rather than where you are.

You do have problem sets available though, from MIT OCR at https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/mathematics/18-02-multivariable-calculus-fall-2007/.  With experience, you will see a Taylor expansion and you will know a Taylor expansion has been used, without anyone having to point it out for you.

I know that this is a necropost and speedfork's response is really good but I want to also point out that  these aren't the only tutorials on the internet. 3Blue1Brown's videos on the Taylor Series makes it super intuitive.   It is also worth noting, that the prof. doesn't take the time to break down what a taylor expansion is. If you have no prior knowledge, you wouldn't be expected to understand this. He was using it to prove a point and help demonstrate how you could use calculus instead of something he's expected you to master immediately. I think you've just panicked a little here and make this to be much worse than it actually is.

He used the Taylor approximation up to the third derivative in both cases. You see, for sin(theta) the zeroth and second derivatives are sin or -sin and for argument 0 they give a value 0 which deletes the whole part like (t^2/2)*f''(0). And in the case of cosine, the first and third derivatives are -sin and sin and they give a value 0 for argument=0.  I hope I answered your question well. Cheers

To treenabalds,  It's because the second derivative of sinθ is -sinθ, it is EXCATLY zero when you plug θ=0. That is, f''(0)=0.  And for cosθ, the first and third derivatives are EXCATLY zero when you plug θ=0. That is, f'(0) and f'''(0) are zero.

Can anyone clarify why (at 48:01) he sets sin(θ) ≈ θ  θ^3/6, leaving out the second degree term (θ^2/2) as it seems should have been next according to the Taylor expansion? He doesnt do that when setting cos(θ) ≈ 1  θ^2/2. I keep thinking about it but cant figure out what Im missing.

Thank you to you, a guy from 12 years ago.

Every even derivative of sine at zero is equal zero. Hence, every taylor approximation term containing even derivative of sine will be equal zero. Cosine is the similar, but with odd derivatives. Thats why linear approximation of sine x is x -> sin(x) ~ sin(0) + dsin(x)/dx * x = 0 + cos(0)*x = 0 + 1 * x = x . Next better approximation will be at Taylor n = 3 -> sin(x) = x - (x^3)/6 , since x + 0 (taylor with n = 2) doesn’t give us any new information comparing to taylor n = 1
